video.title: Full Stack Web App using Vue.js & Express.js: Part 7 - Wrapping Up
video.description:
Welcome to part 7 of a new series where I will create a full stack web application using Vue.js and Express.js

GitHub repo: https://github.com/codyseibert/tab-tracker

Follow Cody on Twitter: https://twitter.com/CodyLSeibert

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.com

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.com

topLevelComment.author: DEEPAK K Sairam Poly
topLevelComment.text: Great video thank you bro

topLevelComment.author: Utkarsh Sharma
topLevelComment.text: please also explain how do we deploy this?

topLevelComment.author: Olatunbosun Dare
topLevelComment.text: Great tutorial, I loved the debugging aspect, plus, although, quite outdated due to updated binaries, it was still fun trying to troubleshoot failures due to upgraded or depreciated binaries. As a take-home, I was able to create metas for the protected routes using the $store parameters to redirect users to the login page with a message prompting that they have to log in in order to view that resource. Fun stuff....

topLevelComment.author: Anh Nguyễn Hoàng

topLevelComment.author: Juan Sm
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks man, very useful!


You go very fast BUT that works great for me. I decide whether if I want to stop for a minute or rewind a bit. I hate slow repetitive tutorials because I can only sit and wait, and then I get distracted. This is better for me.


I liked the debugging bits because even if I was writing right along side you, sometimes I made typos. But since I saw you debugging, I knew how to look for my errors. So that was good too.




The only thing I'd have to say is that for someone who's just starting with these, going back and forth when you decide to go in a different way and start deleting what we wrote sometimes made me lose sight on what we were doing. Maybe a little more planning.


Other than that, 10/10.

replies.author: 卧剑看云
Quincy Koots
replies.text: Thanks for your replay.. One more thing.. Do I still need to upload both the client and the server directories separately to Heroku or just only the server directory? I only uploaded the server directory to Heroku and now I get the "CANNOT GET / " message.

replies.author: 卧剑看云
replies.text:
a. get the index.js under /config and modify as

index: path.resolve(__dirname, '../../server/dist/index.html'),
    assetsRoot: path.resolve(__dirname, '../../server/dist'),

to build dist on server 
b. add  app.use('/uploads', express.static('uploads')) in app.js on server
c.  switch to mongodb, there will be a lot of modification jobs at this step,but it will work out for sure.

topLevelComment.author: YesImHere
topLevelComment.text:
Cody, with all due respect (I am truly enjoying this tutorial series) I was wondering if your returned bookmark data could be modified.  It appears to me you're trying to make the data cleaner which I agree with 100%.  However, you're including the tab and lyrics, etc where they are not needed.  And, if the user has a bunch of bookmarks and a slow connection (or is paying for data) that can always be a problem.  So, I modified the map statements a little:

.map(bookmark => bookmark.toJSON())
.map(bookmark => _.extend({},{
bookmarkId: bookmark.id,
songId: bookmark.Song.id,
title: bookmark.Song.title,
artist: bookmark.Song.artist

Now you only get the actual information you need.  What do you think?
Thanks again!

replies.author: Jim Long
replies.text: I hosted mine on Google Cloud App Engine.  I changed the client's npm run build to put the dist folder on the server folder and then in server/src/app.js add app.use(express.static('dist')).  I ended up using MongoDB/mongoose so I was able to host the DB on mlab.

replies.author: Yoshi Mungus
replies.text:
EDIT: It's always funny how I search 10 billion hours on google to find the answer to my question, then when I give up and actually start to ask for help, I find the answer 10 minutes later...

Anyways, to anyone looking to find out the answer to this using AWS, look no further: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41250087/how-to-deploy-reactjs-nodejs-express-application-onto-aws/41250688#41250688

ORIGINAL QUESTION:
Could you elaborate on this a bit further? I like the way you scaffolded the project, but I am a bit confused on how in production it would play out.

In dev mode, I understand what's going on. You have a client server (8080) and a API server (8081) that are essentially connected by the AJAX call via Axios.

But for production, correct me if I'm wrong, but I'm under the assumption that you are not going to have those two servers anymore so you are going to have to modify to the AJAX call to the correct endpoint (where in dev mode it was just http://localhost:8081/). What I'm stuck on is: What exactly is that new endpoint going to be and how do you host it? Perhaps for simplicity sake, how would I go about hosting this for production using the service you mentioned called Amazon S3?

Thank you for the awesome tutorial!

replies.author: Em Ji Madhu
replies.text: yes you do

topLevelComment.author: DeNiE714
topLevelComment.text:
Help me please!!
After pressing "Set As Bookmark" the song is added to "Bookmarks", and "Unset As Bookmark" appears, you can delete the song from "Bookmarks". BUT if you leave the page of the song, and then go back in, then "Set As Bookmark" appears again. But in fact it is already added, in what a problem?

replies.author: YesImHere
replies.text: Theoretically you've already seen the answer but it's in using Mounted.  The bookmark isn't found yet since that component doesn't have the song.  You need to use Watch instead.  If you go back to lesson 6 at the end you'll see the solution to this issue.

Debugging is ok btw

topLevelComment.author: Iain Diamond

replies.author: Noah Cardoza
replies.text: I found you can also define "songId" and "userId" as unique columns (https://github.com/NoahCardoza/tab-tracker/blob/master/server/src/models/History.js ) and then use History.upsert(...) (https://github.com/NoahCardoza/tab-tracker/blob/master/server/src/controllers/HistoryController.js ) which will create or update an entry with matching unique columns.

topLevelComment.author: skaap2008
topLevelComment.text: Small issue with the recently viewed list of songs. On the backend side, you get the list of recently viewed, then deduplicate it, and then you sort it on the frontend side. The issue here is that you're not sorting before deduplicating, so you're not guaranteed the latest record for each song, you're just guaranteeing any one of the records per song.

replies.author: Jakob Kühne

replies.author: Henn Josef
replies.text: Hey Jakob, can you help me at this Point? i cant get connected to my mysql database. im Dump :( . Perhaps you can give me a Little hint <3@Jakob Kühne

replies.author: Jakob Kühne
replies.text:
I had the same question. But after short research. He is implementing sequelize in Part 2. On the Website of Sequelize they tell you how to connect to xyz external database. You only have to change the config.js created in this Tutorial (Part 2 ~11:45 min) and use for example for mysql [dialect: 'mysql'] and remove the storage option because you only need it for sqlite. Thats it. If you don't hat it installed, you have to install mysql2 (npm install mysql2).

I hope I could help. One Year later, but I'm new in that topic, sorry. More information and really good documentation at the Sequelize Website.
